WorkItem.Description:
Great work on sourcemap support in 0.8.1.  Being able to debug typescript code in Visual Studio is super useful.  

Is it possible to take this one step future and attach Visual Studio to an application running in node.js?  I believe this could be accomplished with the following:

Create a node.js Visual Studio project type.
Set a startup script file (program.ts)
The run action would:
	Open a console window 
	Execute "node program.ts"
	When the process exited, pause with "Press any key to continue..."
The debug action would: 
	Open a console window 
	Execute "node --debug={RANDOM_PORT} program.ts"
	Visual Studio would connect to {RANDOM_PORT} on localhost
	Some Visual Studio debugger magic to interact with the node debug service
	Use source maps to show typecript instead of javascript
(Optinal) Add the ability to attach to and debug a running node process
	In *nix enviornments this is possible by signallying node using kill -s USR1 {PID}, not sure what a similar funciton in windows would look like

https://github.com/dannycoates/node-inspector is a great example application which allows for interactive node debugging.  It uses the debbuger interfaces built into webkit browsers.
WorkItem.Summary: node.js application debugging in Visual Studio

Comments.Message:
There is already an open-source VS extension that does Node.js debugging ... if this could be integrated and improved into VS by MS it would be great.

http://visualstudiogallery.msdn.microsoft.com/bcac44d9-4b9d-45cd-b95e-f19929ac3831

The source for the same extension is available on Github at:

https://github.com/omgtehlion/NodeVsDebugger

I tried building the Typescript branch of that open source project but didn't have much luck with it. Looks like WebStorms is the only option for people who want to use Typescript from front to back....for now.
